articles.headline: A Guide to Getting Rid of Your Big-Bank Checking Account
articles.snippet: If the recent Wells Fargo scandal has left you disenchanted with giant banks and ready to switch to a smaller one or a credit union, here’s what you should know.
articles.abstract: If the recent Wells Fargo scandal has left you disenchanted with giant banks and ready to switch to a smaller one or a credit union, here’s what you should know.
articles.lead_paragraph: When John Stumpf, the embattled chief executive of Wells Fargo, appeared before the House Financial Services Committee on Sept. 29 and swore to tell the truth, Representative Brad Sherman, Democrat of California, noted that he and his colleagues were engaged in “an important national ritual.”
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: U.S. Says Russia Directed Hacks to Influence Elections
articles.snippet: The government formally accused the Kremlin of stealing and disclosing emails from the Democratic National Committee and other sources.
articles.abstract: The government formally accused the Kremlin of stealing and disclosing emails from the Democratic National Committee and other sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday formally accused the Russian government of stealing and disclosing emails from the Democratic National Committee and a range of other institutions and prominent individuals, immediately raising the issue of whether President Obama would seek sanctions or other retaliation.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Isn’t the Only Firm That Needs a Lesson
articles.snippet: Some top private equity firms have been accused of putting their interests ahead of their clients’, but state pension officials still do business with them.
articles.abstract: Some top private equity firms have been accused of putting their interests ahead of their clients’, but state pension officials still do business with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under siege for setting up thousands of phony customer accounts to generate fees, Wells Fargo has taken a beating in Congress and the court of public opinion. Several states have piled on, announcing that they are temporarily cutting their business ties with the bank.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Mylan to Settle EpiPen Overpricing Case for $465 Million
articles.snippet: The government said Mylan had wrongly claimed EpiPen as a generic, leading Medicare and Medicaid to overpay for it. The company said the settlement included no admission of wrongdoing.
articles.abstract: The government said Mylan had wrongly claimed EpiPen as a generic, leading Medicare and Medicaid to overpay for it. The company said the settlement included no admission of wrongdoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mylan, the maker of the allergy treatment EpiPen, said Friday that it had reached a $465 million settlement with the Justice Department and other government agencies over questions on whether the company had overcharged Medicaid for the treatment by improperly classifying it as a generic drug.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Donald Trump Apology Caps Day of Outrage Over Lewd Tape
articles.snippet: A vulgar discussion recorded in 2005 on a soap opera set added to evidence that Mr. Trump has a record of sexist behavior.
articles.abstract: A vulgar discussion recorded in 2005 on a soap opera set added to evidence that Mr. Trump has a record of sexist behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump issued an unusual videotaped apology early Saturday after a 2005 recording surfaced that showed him speaking in extraordinarily vulgar terms about women, setting off an uproar in the Republican Party.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Salesforce Shareholders Besiege Possible Twitter Deal
articles.snippet: To make acquisitions, Salesforce relies on stock and therefore needs to keep its shareholders happy. And they are not interested in a Twitter deal.
articles.abstract: To make acquisitions, Salesforce relies on stock and therefore needs to keep its shareholders happy. And they are not interested in a Twitter deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The investor pressure began building on Marc Benioff, chief executive of Salesforce.com, two weeks ago.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: Jane Pauley Is Back — Again
articles.snippet: Ms. Pauley was quick to point out the fairly incredible timing of her “Sunday Morning” debut: It will occur almost 40 years after her first day as a co-host on “Today.”
articles.abstract: Ms. Pauley was quick to point out the fairly incredible timing of her “Sunday Morning” debut: It will occur almost 40 years after her first day as a co-host on “Today.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Jane Pauley’s daytime talk show was canceled 11 years ago, she thought that might be it for her.
articles.byline: By John Koblin

articles.headline: Peace Prize Seen Not Necessarily for Achievements, but Hopes
articles.snippet: Recent recipients — President Obama, the European Union and now President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia — suggest it is more an encouragement to persevere.
articles.abstract: Recent recipients — President Obama, the European Union and now President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia — suggest it is more an encouragement to persevere.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just weeks after President Obama won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009, he ordered 30,000 additional American troops to Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: As Hurricane Matthew Blows Past, Florida Sighs With Relief
articles.snippet: The storm passed with out the catastrophic effects forecasters had predicted, and on Friday, residents began to return to areas that had been evacuated.
articles.abstract: The storm passed with out the catastrophic effects forecasters had predicted, and on Friday, residents began to return to areas that had been evacuated.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUTCHINSON ISLAND, Fla. — As Hurricane Matthew doused the north Florida coast with floodwaters, high winds and rain, the mood across much of the state shifted from alarm to relief on Friday as the worst of the storm passed by without the catastrophic effects forecasters had predicted and some residents began to return to areas that had been evacuated.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez, Richard Pérez-Peña and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Toll Rises by Hour in Haiti Amid Ruin Left by Hurricane Matthew
articles.snippet: Some estimates said that more than 800 people had died in the storm, and passage to many areas remained blocked, thwarting efforts to help survivors.
articles.abstract: Some estimates said that more than 800 people had died in the storm, and passage to many areas remained blocked, thwarting efforts to help survivors.
articles.lead_paragraph: LES CAYES, Haiti — A hospital now a shambles, its floors swamped with garbage and water, absent electricity. People living in the streets, camped in front of their broken homes. Buildings smashed into splinters. Farm fields flattened, portending a hard year ahead.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: An Investor’s Plan to Transplant Private Health Care in Africa
articles.snippet: A private equity firm is aiming at an emerging middle class that can afford to hire private doctors and avoid the difficult conditions of public hospitals.
articles.abstract: A private equity firm is aiming at an emerging middle class that can afford to hire private doctors and avoid the difficult conditions of public hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The eyes of the private equity investor lit up as he strode across the empty floor of a recently built hospital here. There was not much to see: a stretch of unfinished concrete, and steel bars pushed into a corner.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Swarovski, Maker of All Things Bejeweled, Tries On a Hoodie
articles.snippet: In a village in the Austrian Alps, Swarovski, which has been making crystals for more than a century, is refashioning itself as a tech company.
articles.abstract: In a village in the Austrian Alps, Swarovski, which has been making crystals for more than a century, is refashioning itself as a tech company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATTENS, Austria — A group of millennial programmers swapped jokes recently in their office’s well-stocked kitchen while preparing salads for a weekly barbecue. Others mingled around a new foosball table, playfully arguing over the prospective teams.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott

articles.headline: How U.S. Torture Left a Legacy of Damaged Minds
articles.snippet: Beatings, sleep deprivation, menacing and other brutal tactics have led to persistent mental health problems among detainees held in secret C.I.A. prisons and at Guantánamo.
articles.abstract: Beatings, sleep deprivation, menacing and other brutal tactics have led to persistent mental health problems among detainees held in secret C.I.A. prisons and at Guantánamo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the United States permitted a terrifying way of interrogating prisoners, government lawyers and intelligence officials assured themselves of one crucial outcome. They knew that the methods inflicted on terrorism suspects would be painful, shocking and far beyond what the country had ever accepted. But none of it, they concluded, would cause long lasting psychological harm.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Sheri Fink and James Risen

articles.headline: Lewd Donald Trump Tape Is a Breaking Point for Many in the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Pressure built on the candidate to withdraw from the presidential campaign as party leaders urged the G.O.P. to shift its focus to down-ballot contests.
articles.abstract: Pressure built on the candidate to withdraw from the presidential campaign as party leaders urged the G.O.P. to shift its focus to down-ballot contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders began to abandon Donald J. Trump by the dozens on Saturday after the release of a video showing him speaking of women in vulgar sexual terms, delivering a punishing blow to his campaign and plunging the party into crisis a month before the election.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Seeing ‘Nothing to Live For’ as Haiti Seeks a Body Count After Hurricane Matthew
articles.snippet: Nearly 900 have been reported dead, but the toll is difficult to determine as the country struggles to recover from the devastating storm.
articles.abstract: Nearly 900 have been reported dead, but the toll is difficult to determine as the country struggles to recover from the devastating storm.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-SALUT, Haiti — The loss in this coastal town is all but entire. Dead animals float in tidal pools. Cinder-block heaps mark where homes once stood. Trees, stripped of leaves, branches and tops, impale the earth like ragged posts.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Conduct Was Excused Again and Again. But Not This Time.
articles.snippet: It turns out that even the most self-interested members of the political class, the true weather vanes swinging in the wind, have their limits.
articles.abstract: It turns out that even the most self-interested members of the political class, the true weather vanes swinging in the wind, have their limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump promised to turn Muslims away from American shores, they wagged their fingers.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Donald Trump the Showman, Now Caught in the Klieg Lights
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump deftly used the blending of news and entertainment to build a brand, and then a campaign. But all that drama has turned into a big, messy show.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump deftly used the blending of news and entertainment to build a brand, and then a campaign. But all that drama has turned into a big, messy show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Above all else, the success of Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign was made possible by the media environment in which it was spawned, and his canny ability to exploit it. Now that same environment could very well be the thing that destroys it.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Queen of Reinvention Takes on ‘Rocky Horror’
articles.snippet: Gail Berman, who has championed women throughout her career, is known for her resilience, audacity and taste.
articles.abstract: Gail Berman, who has championed women throughout her career, is known for her resilience, audacity and taste.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — In the late 1990s, still the dark ages for female executives in Hollywood, Dolly Parton invited a young woman to lunch.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Looking for a Choice of Voices in A.I. Technology
articles.snippet: Choosing a voice, which is often young and female, in conversational computing has implications for design, branding or interacting with machines.
articles.abstract: Choosing a voice, which is often young and female, in conversational computing has implications for design, branding or interacting with machines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jason Mars is an African-American professor of computer science who also runs a tech start-up. When his company’s artificially intelligent smartphone app talks, he said, it sounds “like a helpful, young Caucasian female.”
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: A Roar at a Funeral, and Yemen’s War Is Altered
articles.snippet: A deadly series of airstrikes believed to be from a Saudi-led coalition have unleashed political forces that could drastically change the conflict.
articles.abstract: A deadly series of airstrikes believed to be from a Saudi-led coalition have unleashed political forces that could drastically change the conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Large speakers played verses from the Quran as hundreds of mourners filed through the fanciest reception hall in Sana, the capital, to pay their respects to a prominent family after the death of its patriarch.
articles.byline: By Shuaib Almosawa and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: In Second Debate, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Spar in Bitter, Personal Terms
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton accused each other of mistreating women and signaled that the final month of the presidential race would be an ugly political brawl.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton accused each other of mistreating women and signaled that the final month of the presidential race would be an ugly political brawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton collided in an almost unremittingly hostile debate on Sunday night, a 90-minute spectacle of character attacks, tawdry allegations, and Mr. Trump’s startling accusation that Mrs. Clinton had “tremendous hate in her heart.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Donald Trump Talks at Debate, but Many Women Hear Only a 2005 Tape
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump may have uttered words about unfair trade deals or threats to national security, but what some voters heard instead was his voice on that searing recording.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump may have uttered words about unfair trade deals or threats to national security, but what some voters heard instead was his voice on that searing recording.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was Donald J. Trump’s chance to sound contrite and mature, to explain away the sexually predatory boasts he was caught making on tape and to persuade Americans that — for all his no-apologies braggadocio — he was, in fact, capable of feeling shame.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Donald Trump Acknowledges Not Paying Federal Income Taxes for Years
articles.snippet: The admission of using a loss to avoid future taxes came in response to a question at Sunday’s debate with Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: The admission of using a loss to avoid future taxes came in response to a question at Sunday’s debate with Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump explicitly acknowledged for the first time during Sunday’s debate that he used a $916 million loss that he reported on his 1995 income tax returns to avoid paying personal federal income taxes for years.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Megan Twohey

articles.headline: Samsung Halts Galaxy Note 7 Production as Battery Problems Linger
articles.snippet: The move is a major setback for the world’s largest producer of smartphones, which had been gaining ground against Apple in the high-end market.
articles.abstract: The move is a major setback for the world’s largest producer of smartphones, which had been gaining ground against Apple in the high-end market.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1995, furious over quality problems with one of his company’s mobile phones, Lee Kun-hee, the chairman of Samsung and arguably the most famous businessman in South Korea, set a pile of 150,000 defective phones on fire outside a factory.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Choe Sang-Hun and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Paul Ryan Turns Focus From Donald Trump to House Races, Roiling G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The House speaker told Republicans that he would focus on defending the party’s majority in Congress, while hard-liners urged colleagues to keep backing Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: The House speaker told Republicans that he would focus on defending the party’s majority in Congress, while hard-liners urged colleagues to keep backing Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: The House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, dealt a hammer blow to Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy on Monday, dashing any remaining semblance of Republican unity and inviting fierce backlash from his own caucus by announcing that he would no longer defend Mr. Trump.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: In Haiti, a City’s Race Into the 21st Century Is Ruined by a Hurricane
articles.snippet: Along with hundreds of lives, the storm wiped out much of the progress that the isolated city, Jérémie, had been making.
articles.abstract: Along with hundreds of lives, the storm wiped out much of the progress that the isolated city, Jérémie, had been making.
articles.lead_paragraph: JÉRÉMIE, Haiti — Things had been looking up in Jérémie, a coastal city marooned on the tip of Haiti’s southern peninsula. It had recently gotten its first decent road link to the rest of the country, a new highway through the rugged mountains that brought development. Cellphone service had finally begun, enabling farmers and businesses to flourish. The city was racing into the 21st century, dreaming of advanced agriculture and tourism in one of Haiti’s few nature preserves.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed
